in his 8-year-old campaign to bring home ancient artifacts spirited out of the country during colonial times. Zahi Hawass wants to see back home. The bust is currently at Berlin's Neues Museum. I am doing something that I believe in and that should have been done a hundred years ago, Zahi Hawass said. "My campaign has united those who have been pillaged against the pillagers. It's the world's greatest campaign of its kind and has inspired many nations to follow suit."

it surprising that Washington Examiner writer Mike Pence Barone would contend "old rules don't apply to" the 2012 Republican primary election campaign even though every Republican presidential nominee since Ronald Reagan in 1980 has been pro-life. The next rule that needs to be debunked is that Republican candidates must pass a litmus test on cultural issues, especially abortion. This was true in 1988, 1996 and 2000, when religious conservatives were a newly energized political force and one stirred to action by Bill Clinton 's misconduct, he writes. "But Sept. 11 changed a lot of things, including this old rule. A pro-choice stand on abortion didn't prevent Rudy Giuliani from leading Republican polls until November 2007
